fat containing tumor in the abdomen: Intra-abdominal lipomatous neoplasm - Mass lesion containing macroscopic fat (CT attenuation -30 to -190 HU), commonly seen in adrenal myelolipoma, retroperitoneal liposarcoma, or renal angiomyolipoma
post op in the abdomen: Postoperative abdominal changes - Includes surgical site edema, granulation tissue, metallic implant artifacts, and postoperative fluid collections indicating recent surgical intervention
adrenal pathology in the abdomen: Adrenal gland pathology - Spectrum of adrenal abnormalities including hyperplasia (>10mm thickness), adenoma (<10 HU), pheochromocytoma, or metastatic disease
bil dil in the abdomen: Biliary dilation - Pathological dilatation of intrahepatic (>2mm) or extrahepatic (>8mm) bile ducts, demonstrating 'double duct sign' or 'soft vine sign' on imaging
osseous neoplasm in the abdomen: Abdominal osseous neoplasm - Destructive bone lesion with osteolytic/osteoblastic changes and associated soft tissue mass in spine/pelvis, suggestive of primary bone tumor or metastasis
ovarian pathology in the abdomen: Ovarian pathology - Adnexal complex cystic-solid masses including dermoids (fat density), cystadenomas/carcinomas, or endometriomas (T1-hyperintense cysts)
soft tissue collection in the abdomen: Abdominal soft tissue collection - Poorly defined fluid/soft tissue density accumulations, differential includes abscess (rim enhancement), hematoma (hyperdense acute phase), or loculated fluid
bowel inflammation in the abdomen: Enteric inflammatory changes - Bowel wall stratification ('target sign'), mucosal edema (hypodense layer), and mesenteric fat stranding ('fat halo sign')
gallbladder pathology in the abdomen: Gallbladder pathology - Spectrum including wall thickening (>3mm), porcelain gallbladder (calcified wall), or pericholecystic fluid collections
gallstone in the abdomen: Cholelithiasis - Radiopaque calcifications in gallbladder/bile ducts (CT >100 HU), with possible 'meniscus sign' or 'rolling stone sign'
prostate lesion in the abdomen: Prostatic lesion - Irregular gland contour, extracapsular extension, or focal enhancement, differential includes carcinoma (elevated PSA) versus BPH
renal lesion in the abdomen: Renal space-occupying lesion - Enhancing mass on corticomedullary phase (Bosniak classification), differential includes RCC ('washout' enhancement), lipid-poor AML, or complex cyst
soft tissue mass in the abdomen: Abdominal soft tissue mass - Non-organ based solid lesion requiring evaluation of enhancement pattern, necrosis, and local invasion
degenerative changes in the abdomen: Degenerative changes - Osteophyte formation, disc space narrowing, facet hypertrophy, or vertebral endplate Modic changes
abnormal entire organ in the abdomen: Diffuse organ abnormality - Global morphological/density alterations such as hepatic steatosis (CT<40 HU), cirrhotic morphology, or splenomegaly
bowel abnormality in the abdomen: Bowel abnormality - Includes wall thickening (small bowel>3mm, colon>5mm), luminal distension (small bowel>2.5cm), or mesenteric vascular abnormalities
dilated urinary tract in the abdomen: Hydronephrosis/hydroureter - Pelvicalyceal system dilatation (renal pelvis>10mm) or ureteral dilatation (>7mm)
splenic lesion in the abdomen: Splenic lesion - Hypodense splenic foci, differential includes cyst (non-enhancing), hemangioma (centripetal enhancement), or lymphoma (mild homogeneous enhancement)
ascites in the abdomen: Peritoneal ascites - Free fluid in hepatorenal recess/pelvis (CT 0-30 HU), categorized as simple/complex with high density suggesting exudate
pancreatic lesion in the abdomen: Pancreatic lesion - Focal pancreatic abnormalities including pseudocyst (non-enhancing), IPMN ('cluster of grapes sign'), or adenocarcinoma ('double duct sign')
arterial pathology in the abdomen: Arteriopathy - Vascular abnormalities including aneurysm (>3cm diameter), dissection (intimal flap), calcification, or thromboembolism (filling defect)
bowel mass in the abdomen: Bowel mass - Luminal/transmural mass causing luminal narrowing, with features like 'apple-core sign' (carcinoma) or 'target sign' (GIST)
intraperitoneal mass in the abdomen: Intraperitoneal neoplasm - Peritoneal/mesenteric-based tumors including omental caking (carcinomatosis), mesothelioma, or pseudomyxoma peritonei
liver lesion in the abdomen: Hepatic lesion - Focal liver lesions demonstrating enhancement patterns like centrifugal enhancement (hemangioma), 'target sign' (metastases), or central scar (FNH)
urolithiasis in the abdomen: Urinary calculi - Radiopaque calculi in urinary system (CT>500 HU), classified as nephrolithiasis, ureterolithiasis ('soft tissue rim sign'), or cystolithiasis
uterine pathology in the abdomen: Uterine pathology - Spectrum including endometrial thickening (>5mm postmenopausal), fibroids (T2-hypointense), or endometrial carcinoma (myometrial invasion)
bladder pathology in the abdomen: Vesical pathology - Focal bladder wall thickening/masses, differential includes papilloma (pedunculated), carcinoma (sessile), or diverticulum
normal in the abdomen: Normal abdominal imaging - All organs demonstrate expected morphology, density, and enhancement without mass, inflammation, or obstruction
airspace opacity in the lung: Increased lung density caused by filling of alveoli with fluid, pus, blood or cells. Appears as homogeneous opacification on imaging, often obscuring pulmonary vessels. Characteristic of pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or hemorrhage.
parenchyma destruction in the lung: Irreversible loss of normal lung architecture due to tissue necrosis. Typically seen in advanced emphysema (alveolar wall breakdown) or cavitary diseases like tuberculosis, appearing as decreased attenuation and bullae/cysts formation.
interstitial lung disease in the lung: Group of disorders causing inflammation and fibrosis of pulmonary interstitium. Includes IPF, sarcoidosis and hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Characterized by reticular opacities, honeycombing and traction bronchiectasis on CT.
bronchiectasis in the lung: Irreversible bronchial dilation with wall thickening. Classified as cylindrical, varicose or cystic. Causes chronic cough and recurrent infections.
nodule in the lung: Discrete pulmonary opacity â‰¤3cm in diameter. Requires monitoring for malignant features (spiculation, growth) versus benign causes.
normal in the lung: Normal chest imaging - Clear lung fields with well-defined bronchovascular bundles, without consolidation, nodules, or interstitial abnormalities
